The Event Management program at George Brown College offers a 14-week externship placement and a final capstone event. Students learn industry tactics in event design, planning, marketing, budgeting, execution, and evaluation. Management skills, small business development, and state-of-the-art technology are explored. The program is taught both online and through in-class lectures.

The Field Education Options include a final capstone event, a mandatory 14-week externship placement, and opportunities for self-directed industry work experience. Students may pursue work experience that provides the desired learning experiences and meets the program's learning outcomes to add to their resumé.

Career Opportunities after completing the Event Management program include roles such as event planner, conference planner, meeting planner, catering manager, incentive travel manager, festival planner, social event planner, event fundraiser, and volunteer coordinator.

Qualified graduates of the Event Planning program may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program at George Brown College as an advanced standing student in September or January. The educational path requires a minimum grade point average of 2.7 to qualify.

Required Courses for the first semester include:
- HOST1085: Principles of Hospitality and Tourism Management
- HOST1171: Global Accommodation Industry
- HOST1172: Introduction to Wines and Beverages
- HOST1070: Introduction to Catering
- HOST1146: Leading, Following and Speaking with Confidence.

No factual information such as years, numbers, emails, or names were extracted from the text.

No factual information such as years, numbers, emails, or names were extracted from the text.

SEMESTERS AND COURSES:
- Semester 1: HOST1146 (Leading, Following and Speaking with Confidence), COMM2000 (Communicating Across Contexts), MATH1250 (Introduction to Management Numeracy with Excel Applications), HOST1068 (Smart Serve - online certificate), HOSF1145 (Sanitation - online certificate), HOSF1146 (Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR - weekend course)
- Semester 2: HOST1174 (Remarkable Restaurant Service – An Introduction to the Industry), HOST1043 (Special Events Planning and Delivery), HOST1173 (Hospitality Marketing and Social Media), HOST1160 (Career Preparation), HOST1175 (Global Tourism), HRM1015 (Human Resources Management), LAW1017 (Introduction to Hospitality Law), ACCT1048 (Hospitality Accounting), GSCI1035 (Science of Sustainability)
- Semester 3: HOST1097 (Meetings and Conferences), HOST1139 (Technical Meeting and Event Production), HOST2066 (Event Operations I), HOST2077 (Building Your Special Event Business), HOST2091 (Budgeting for Special Events), HOST1129 (Selling Special Events), HOST2072 (Volunteer Management), GNED (General Education Elective)
- Semester 4: HOST2063 (Events Operations II - Capstone Event Project), HOST2141 (Industry Externship), GNED (General Education Elective)

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
- Some courses have a duration of 7 weeks (*)
- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000. This course does not count as a required course for graduation and students will be charged extra.
- General Education Electives are specified by the code GNED.
- Course names provide information about the content of each course (e.g., Remarkable Restaurant Service, Special Events Planning, Human Resources Management, etc.)

PROGRAM LEARNING OUTCOMES:
The graduate will be able to:
1. Plan and design events to meet organizational and client objectives.
2. Select food and beverage catering services, site location and decor, according to the theme and needs of an event.
3. Develop marketing plans and related promotional plans for events that will meet the needs of the organization and/or client.
4. Coordinate and/or supervise staff, contractors and volunteers in order to achieve the desired results.

- Semester 3: HOST1097 (Meetings and Conferences), HOST1139 (Technical Meeting and Event Production), HOST2066 (Event Operations I), HOST2077 (Building Your Special Event Business), HOST2091 (Budgeting for Special Events), HOST1129 (Selling Special Events), HOST2072 (Volunteer Management), GNED (General Education Elective)
- Semester 4: HOST2063 (Events Operations II - Capstone Event Project), HOST2141 (Industry Externship), GNED (General Education Elective)

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
- Some courses have a duration of 7 weeks (*)
- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000. This course does not count as a required course for graduation and students will be charged extra.
- General Education Electives are specified by the code GNED.
- Course names provide information about the content of each course (e.g., Remarkable Restaurant Service, Special Events Planning, Human Resources Management, etc.)

PROGRAM LEARNING OUTCOMES:
The graduate will be able to:
1. Plan and design events to meet organizational and client objectives.
2. Select food and beverage catering services, site location and decor, according to the theme and needs of an event.
3. Develop marketing plans and related promotional plans for events that will meet the needs of the organization and/or client.
4. Coordinate and/or supervise staff, contractors and volunteers in order to achieve the desired results.

The text provides information on various responsibilities involved in event management at the college, along with tuition fees and financial assistance details for a specific program. Here's the extracted information:

1. Event Management Responsibilities:
   - Coordinate and supervise staff, contractors, and volunteers.
   - Implement best practices for financial management.
   - Manage business transactions of event projects.
   - Develop risk mitigation strategies.
   - Maintain ethical practices and professionalism.
   - Support intercultural awareness and inclusion.
   - Use industry-standard technology platforms.
   - Secure sponsorships, funds, or grants.
   - Engage in ongoing learning and career opportunities.
   - Communicate information effectively.

2. Tuition Fees for Fall 2022:
   - Domestic Students: $4,545.00 (total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees)
   - International Students: $18,547.00

3. Additional Costs:
   - Textbooks, manuals, etc.: $575 (subject to change)
   - Includes a uniform: black pants, grey Oxford shirt, and a bib apron

4. Financial Assistance:
   - Approved for OSAP funding, provided applicant meets eligibility criteria.

5. Admission Requirements:
   - Applicants selected based on academic achievement, including Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and Grade 12 English.

Please note that fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later dates. Additionally, international students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.

* Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent is required for admission.
* Grade 12 English with a minimum grade of C or U is necessary.
* Applicants can qualify through the Hospitality Services (Pre-Hospitality) program (H101), but seats are limited and admission is not guaranteed.
* Mature students (19 years of age or older without an OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to achieve the required English credit.
* George Brown College grants course exemptions based on college or university credits, more information can be found in the Transfer Guide.
* International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Allergens including nuts, dairy, and shellfish are used in practical labs.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.
* For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage.
* Financial inquiries can be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or their webpage.
* Event Planning (H141) inquiries should be sent to chcastudentsupport@georgebrown.ca.
* For more information, contact the George Brown College Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-XXX-YYYY).

* Applicants can qualify through the Hospitality Services (Pre-Hospitality) program (H101), but seats are limited and admission is not guaranteed.
* Mature students (19 years of age or older without an OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to achieve the required English credit.
* George Brown College grants course exemptions based on college or university credits, more information can be found in the Transfer Guide.
* International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Allergens including nuts, dairy, and shellfish are used in practical labs.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.
* For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage.
* Financial inquiries can be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or their webpage.
* Event Planning (H141) inquiries should be sent to chcastudentsupport@georgebrown.ca.
* For more information, contact the George Brown College Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-XXX-YYYY).
